article-doc.publication: The Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition

alt-summary-body.p: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Aug. 29, 2014

summary-body.p: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Aug. 29, 2014

p.link: Kiev and its backers in the West accused Moscow of sending Russian troops and armor to fight alongside rebels in eastern Ukraine, dimming hopes for a diplomatic solution to the crisis.
Obama signaled the U.S. has no immediate plans to escalate military operations against Islamic State extremists in Iraq or Syria, stressing the need to develop a broader strategy.
Syrian rebels abducted 43 United Nations peacekeepers as the insurgents fought Syrian government forces in the Golan Heights area.
Pakistan's army chief agreed to mediate between the Sharif government and protesters who are demanding that the premier resign.
Nations with the funds and resources to help deal with the Ebola epidemic have so far offered only a trickle of aid.
The NIH will begin testing an experimental Ebola vaccine in humans next week, accelerating research.
Pennsylvania's governor agreed to extend Medicaid to low-income residents under the Affordable Care Act.
The NFL's commissioner told league owners that he is increasing penalties for domestic-violence incidents.
Erdogan was sworn in as Turkey's first popularly elected president, heralding a new political order.

article-body.p: A Thai court dismissed murder charges against ex-premier Abhisit and a deputy over a 2010 crackdown.
